cip.render.raytrace.material

Class Blinn

  • java.lang.Object
    • cip.render.raytrace.material.Blinn
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    IDynXmlObject, INamedObject, IRtMaterial
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    Whitted

    public class Blinn
extends java.lang.Object
implements IDynXmlObject, INamedObject, IRtMaterial
    This is an implementation of the Blinn illumination model as described in Blinn, James F (1977), "Models of Light Reflection for Computer Synthesized Images", ACM Computer Graphics, (SIGGRAPH 77), vol. 11, no. 2, pp.192-198. In this paper, Blinn describes a specular reflection DGF where: D is the slope-distribution function; G is the geometric attenuation function; and F is the Fresnel reflectance. Though Blinn mentions Fresnel reflectance, it is unclear whether it was used in his images. This implementation of the Blinn illumination model supports various implementations of D and G, and sets F to 1.0.

    The Blinn illuminated material is specified as a node in an XML file as:

        <DynamicallyLoadedObject class="cip.raytrace.material.Blinn" name="materialName">
          <colour RGBf_attributes/>
          <beta>betaDegrees</beta>
          <conductor/>
          <dielectric/>
          <DynamicallyLoadedObject class="slopeDistributionFunction"/>
          <DynamicallyLoadedObject class="geometricAttenuationFunction"/>
        </DynamicallyLoadedObject>

    where:
    colour or colour The material colour as specified by the RGBf_attributes which are described in RGBf.setValue().
    emissivity The base material colour in the absense of any lighting as specified by the RGBf_attributes which are described in RGBf.setValue(). Emissivity can be used when an object needs to be a constant colour for chroma-key compositing, or when a material is a light source.
    beta The beta angle, or angle of deviation between N and H when the slope distribution is half the value as when N = H. Valid values are 2 degree to 45 degree. The default is 45 degree if not specified.
    conductor If specified, the material is a conductor and the specular colour is set equal to the material colour. conductor and dielectric are mutually exclusive. If not specified, the material defaults to a dielectric.
    dielectric If specified, the material is a dielectric and the specular colour is 1,1,1. conductor and dielectric are mutually exclusive.
    DynamicallyLoadedObject This is the specification of either the a slope distribution function (the object implements the IRtD interface) or the geometric attenuation function (the object implements the IRtG interface). If not specified, the default slope distribution function is the Blinn function, and the geometric attenuation defaults to a constant value of 1.

    Example of XML Specification

    The following specifies a matte green material using the Phong slope distibution function:

        <DynamicallyLoadedObject class="cip.raytrace.material.Blinn" name="green">
          <colour rgb="0,1,0"/>
          <dielectric/>
          <beta>45</beta>
          <DynamicallyLoadedObject class="cip.raytrace.material.D.Phong"/>
        </DynamicallyLoadedObject>

    Since:
    1.0

        public Blinn(java.lang.String strName,
             RGBf rgbMtl,
             boolean bConductor,
             AngleF aBeta)
        Creates a new instance of the Blinn illumination model.
        Parameters:
        strName - (String) The material name.
        rgbMtl - (RGBf, readonly) The (reflective) material color.
        bConductor - (boolean) true if the material is a coinductor (metallic), false if the material is dielectric (plastic, non-metal))
        aBeta - (AngleF, readonly) The beta angle, or angle of deviation between N and H when the slope distribution is half the value as when N = H. Valid values are 2 degree to 45 degree.

        public void loadFromXml(@NotNull
                        @NotNull org.w3c.dom.Element xmlElement,
                        @Nullable
                        @Nullable java.util.LinkedList refObjectList)
                 throws DynXmlObjParseException
        Description copied from interface: IDynXmlObject
        Loads this object from an XML DOM Document element. The DynXmlObjLoader has parsed the element and attributes to determine that this is a dynamically loaded object, found and instantiated the class, and is now sending the node to the object so it can initialize itself based on the contents of the node.
        Specified by:
        loadFromXml in interface IDynXmlObject
        Parameters:
        xmlElement - The dynamically loaded object DOM Document element.
        refObjectList - A linked list if named objects (implementing the INamedObject interface) that have already been loaded and can be used to resolve object references.
        Throws:
        DynXmlObjParseException - Thrown if there was an error parsing the object. If this exception is thrown it should be assumed that this object was incorrectly initialized, is invalid, and should not be used in any further operations.

      • initSampling

        public void initSampling(int nSample,
                         @NotNull
                         @NotNull float[] f1dSample,
                         float[] f1dRandom,
                         @NotNull
                         @NotNull Point2f[] pt2dSample,
                         Point2f[] pt2dRandom,
                         @NotNull
                         @NotNull Point3f[] pt3dSample,
                         Point3f[] pt3dRandom)
        Description copied from interface: IRtMaterial
        Specifies the sampling arrays that should be used for distributed ray-tracing. Materials that do not participate in distributed ray-tracing will normally ignore this function, or, pass the arrays down to child materials which may make use of the sampling arrays. Normally, these are used for normal perturbations for rough surfaces.
        Specified by:
        initSampling in interface IRtMaterial
        Parameters:
        nSample - The number of sub-samples (over-samples) per pixel.
        f1dSample - (readonly) The 1d sample displacement array. The length of this array will be equal to the number of sub-samples per pixel. This array is for oversampling linear phenomena.
        f1dRandom - (readonly) The 1d 'jitter' array. No assumptions should be made about the length of this array.
        pt2dSample - (readonly) The 2d sample displacement array. The length of this array will be equal to the number of sub-samples per pixel. This array is for oversampling area phenomena.
        pt2dRandom - (readonly) The 2d 'jitter' array. No assumptions should be made about the length of this array.
        pt3dSample - (readonly) The 3d sample displacement array. The length of this array will be equal to the number of sub-samples per pixel. This array is for oversampling volume phenomena.
        pt3dRandom - (readonly) The 3d 'jitter' array. No assumptions should be made about the length of this array.

      • getColor

        public void getColor(@NotNull
                     @NotNull RGBf rgb,
                     @NotNull
                     @NotNull RayIntersection intersection,
                     @NotNull
                     @NotNull IRtLight[] lights,
                     @NotNull
                     @NotNull IRtGeometry[] rtObjects,
                     @NotNull
                     @NotNull IRtBackground rtBkg,
                     int nMaxRecursions,
                     int nSample,
                     int nRandom)
        Description copied from interface: IRtMaterial
        Compute the colour of a surface as seen from a specific direction.
        Specified by:
        getColor in interface IRtMaterial
        Parameters:
        rgb - (modified) The computed colour at the surface.
        intersection - (readonly) The description of the surface - location, orientation, material, etc.
        lights - (readonly) The light in the scene that may affect the intersection.
        rtObjects - (readonly) The objects in the scene.
        rtBkg - (readonly) The background description.
        nMaxRecursions - The maximum reflections to be followed in computing this colour.
        nSample - The pixel sub-sample index. This is used in distributed ray-tracing to make sure the correct sample displacement is used for samples that are distributed.
        nRandom - The jitter array index..
